pullRequest.body:
Definitions of sub-Gaussian and conditionally sub-Gaussian, both as special cases of a definition of sub-Gaussian with respect to a kernel and a measure.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

- [x] depends on: #22622
- [ ] depends on: #22679

See #22433 for the Azuma-Hoeffding inequality for sub-Gaussian random variables.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [3c0c90770e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22623/commits/3c0c90770efd9ecf87a7ec0751fe00ef3a12f9b7)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Probability.Moments.SubGaussian` (new file)|2269|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ HasCondSubgaussianMGF`
`+ HasSubgaussianMGF`
`+ HasSubgaussianMGF_iff_kernel`
`+ _root_.ProbabilityTheory.Kernel.HasSubgaussianMGF_congr`
`+ ae_aestronglyMeasurable`
`+ ae_forall_integrable_exp_mul`
`+ ae_integrable_exp_mul`
`+ condExp_le`
`+ congr`
`+ integrable_exp_mul`
`+ measure_ge_le_exp_add`
`+ of_rat`
`+ prodMkLeft_comp_compProd`
`+ toReal_prob_le_one`
`++ Kernel.HasSubgaussianMGF`
`++ aestronglyMeasurable`
`++ cgf_le`
`++ measure_ge_le`
`++ prob_ge_le`
`+++ fun_zero`
`+++ memLp_exp_mul`
`+++ zero`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#22622~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
Thank you, that's great! Mostly small suggestions with a nice golf for `zero`, I'll get to the conditional part later.
A few more remarks.

You can do this directly (I also dropped the `Measure` namespace)
```suggestion
  rw [â† snd_compProd Î¼ Îº, Kernel.prodMkLeft, snd, â† deterministic_comp_eq_map measurable_snd,
    comp_assoc, Kernel.comp_deterministic_eq_comap]
```

Does this change the rendering in the docs? if not it's nicer to read in the code.
```suggestion
* [R. Vershynin, *High-dimensional probability: An introduction with applications in data
  science*][vershynin2018high]
```

The `simp` + `exact` combo can often be replaced by `simpa`.
```suggestion
  simpa using (aemeasurable_of_aemeasurable_exp h_int.1.aemeasurable).aestronglyMeasurable
```

Yes I know! It's just that while doing that kind of proof I `simp` something to simplify it, then remark that I am able to close the goal with `exact`, and I don't take the trouble to backtrack to see if I could merge some lines.
But thanks for those improvements!

```suggestion
  filter_upwards [h_int] with Ï‰ h_int
  simpa using (aemeasurable_of_aemeasurable_exp h_int.1.aemeasurable).aestronglyMeasurable
```

You can also do that if you want:
```suggestion
  have h_int (n : â„¤) : âˆ€áµ Ï‰' âˆ‚Î½, Integrable (fun Ï‰ â†¦ exp (n * X Ï‰)) (Îº Ï‰') :=
    h.ae_integrable_exp_mul _
```

```suggestion
  Â· simpa [hp0] using (h.integrable_exp_mul t).1
```

There is already a `p` here.
```suggestion
    convert h' using 3 with Ï‰
```

```suggestion
    Â· simpa [h0] using by positivity
```

You don't need `of_rat` here. Also should the name be `fun_zero` and the one below just `zero`?
```suggestion
lemma zero [IsFiniteMeasure Î½] [IsZeroOrMarkovKernel Îº] :
    HasSubgaussianMGF (fun _ â†¦ 0) 0 Îº Î½ where
  integrable_exp_mul := by simp
  mgf_le := by simpa using ae_of_all _ fun _ â†¦ toReal_prob_le_one
```

NIce golf! The definition I had changed something like 4 times, so perhaps `of_rat` was useful at some point? Perhaps not!

I'll change the names, good catch. That code was written before the outcome of that unfortunate poll.

```suggestion
    filter_upwards [h'] with Ï‰ hÏ‰ using by rw [hÏ‰]
```

```suggestion
  âŸ¨fun hX â†¦ congr hX h, fun hY â†¦ congr hY (ae_eq_symm h)âŸ©
```
These two appear in a different order in the file, can you swap them please?
You can use the namespace `HasCondSubgaussianMGF` here.
Maybe this (and also the other versions) should be renamed to `memLp_exp_mul`, like the integrable version, what do you think?
Out of curiosity, why didn't you use this as the definition?

HasSubgaussianMGF is the definition that people would know about. I wanted the def to be what they'd expect.
It has the downside that it forces me to do some rewrites before applying the kernel results.

This is a good reason. Maybe it is worth explaining this in the docstring of the definition. This would prevent people from searching a result about `HasSubgaussianMGF` which in fact is proved for `Kernel.HasSubgaussianMGF`.

Yes I'll add explanations. Also it makes me think that another question could be "why did I not do the same for the conditional definition?". And here the answer is different and would also merit an explanation, which I'll add (in the file docstring for example).

The definition I expected at first would have used an integrability condition together with
```lean
âˆ€áµ Ï‰' âˆ‚(Î¼.trim hm), âˆ€ t, (Î¼[fun Ï‰ â†¦ exp (t * X Ï‰) | m]) Ï‰' â‰¤ exp (c * t ^ 2 / 2)
```
And a subtlety is that this is not the same as what we have with the kernel definition, which is this: 
```lean
âˆ€áµ Ï‰' âˆ‚(Î¼.trim hm), âˆ€ t, mgf X (condExpKernel Î¼ m Ï‰') t â‰¤ exp (c * t ^ 2 / 2)
```
The issue is that the mgf of `condExpKernel` and the conditional expectation are equal `Î¼`-a.e., but not `(Î¼.trim hm)`-a.e.
Also `fun t => (Î¼[fun Ï‰ â†¦ exp (t * X Ï‰) | m]) Ï‰'` is not the mgf of a measure so we can't use mgf properties (`condExpKernel` is defined precisely to have a version of the conditional expectation that corresponds to a measure, and that needs assumptions on the space).

Indeed this is subtle. I certainly find it nicer with `condExpKernel`, and anyway we rarely manipulate conditional expectations without good hypotheses on the space.
This question of `Î¼`-a.e. vs `(Î¼.trim hm)`-a.e. kind of bothers me though. In the past I have already thought that pinning a measure to a `Ïƒ`-algebra was not ideal when I realized that you need to assume `MeasurableSingletonClass` in [MeasureTheory.ae_eq_dirac](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/MeasureTheory/Measure/Dirac.html#MeasureTheory.ae_eq_dirac). Although in that particular case you could get around this by lifting `condExpKernel` to `mÎ©`.

A bit more nuance: the trim a.e. equality is true if we have strong measurability:
```lean
theorem condExp_ae_eq_trim_integral_condExpKernel {F : Type*} [NormedAddCommGroup F] {f : Î© â†’ F}
    [NormedSpace â„ F] [CompleteSpace F] (hm : m â‰¤ mÎ©) (hf : StronglyMeasurable f)
    (hf_int : Integrable f Î¼) :
    Î¼[f|m] =áµ[Î¼.trim hm] fun Ï‰ â†¦ âˆ« y, f y âˆ‚condExpKernel Î¼ m Ï‰ := by
 refine StronglyMeasurable.ae_eq_trim_of_stronglyMeasurable hm ?_ ?_ ?_
 Â· exact stronglyMeasurable_condExp
 Â· exact hf.integral_condExpKernel
 Â· exact condExp_ae_eq_integral_condExpKernel hm hf_int
```
However currently in the sub-Gaussian definitions we would get only `Î¼`-a.e. stong measurability. That's no problem on the left hand side: `Î¼[f|m] =áµ[Î¼.trim hm] Î¼[g|m]` if `f =áµ[Î¼] g` (see #22675) so we can get back to a strongly measurable function there.  But I think that's not true on the right hand side, for `fun Ï‰ â†¦ âˆ« y, f y âˆ‚condExpKernel Î¼ m Ï‰ `.
Or I might be completely wrong and the two statements are actually the same. I'll report back soon.

Indeed I was wrong and I can prove `Î¼[f|m] =áµ[Î¼.trim hm] fun Ï‰ â†¦ âˆ« y, f y âˆ‚condExpKernel Î¼ m Ï‰` if I have only `Integrable f Î¼`.
I'll add that lemma in another PR and change various things here.

```suggestion
  simpa using (aemeasurable_of_aemeasurable_exp h_int.1.aemeasurable).aestronglyMeasurable
```
Do you really need this? For the general version It seemed useful because it allows to swap `âˆ€` and `âˆ€áµ`, but here I am not sure.
I'll remove it.

pullRequest.title: feat(Probability): (conditionally) sub-Gaussian random variables

source.title: feat(Probability): Azuma-Hoeffding inequality for sub-Gaussian random variables
